answers.answer: The thyroid problem should be straight-forward in terms of keeping the TSH in the 0.3-2.5 range with medication -- that is the primary goal of treatment.  Otherwise the anemia is likely due to uterine bleeding but this may not be causing the numbness and weakness.  Would look at B12 and Vitamin D levels.  Sounds like you have had a thorough evaluation.  Treating the uterine fibrosis may be helpful...

question: I have hypothyroidism and have been on replacement medication for over 30 years.  Approximately 5 years ago, I began having difficulties with the medication not working.  My medication was changed; which did not help.  I changed doctors, but his idea of regulating my thyroid was to put me on 3mg of estrogen replacement daily.  This created a large weight gain and did nothing to regulate my thyroid problem.  Subsequently I went to an endocrinologist who got things corrected. However, the last year I have been having new problem culminating with tingling in my hips, down the inside of my legs, becoming numbness in my feet. I also have weakness in my hips and thighs, keeping me from going on walks. I don't have diabetes, Lupis or MS. I am anemic and have an enlarged uterus with fibrois cysts.  A stress test, upper endoscopy, three MRIs, an untrasound a CT and numerous blood tests later, no one seems to know what is wrong.  As I have Hashimoto's disease, wouldn't that be a good place to start?  What are your suggestions?Thank you, Arli
title: Concerned about adequate diagnoses
